intro: Habranthus andersonii var. parvulus, commonly known as the dwarf habranthus, is a small, flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its compact growth habit and delicate, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically produces white or pale blue blooms during the summer months. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it suitable for rock gardens or dry landscapes. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
